Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the attribution of the quote to Mark Twain. There is no source information provided, and efforts to find the quote in Twain's documented writings have been unsuccessful.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Mark Twain said or wrote the quote, but there is no concrete evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the quote, as Mark Twain expressed a similar opinion about the power of a lie in his Autobiography, although the wording is different.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the quote attributed to Mark Twain cannot be found in any of his documented writings.
Understate: The claim may understate the extent to which the attribution of the quote to Mark Twain is unsupported, as it only briefly mentions the lack of source information.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a clear and definitive answer regarding the authenticity of the quote.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence of exaggeration in the claim.
